column1: I have all the symptoms except fever, I went to Medicross and Dr said I can get tested if I want to I'm not sure if I should. She gave me antibiotics Klacid XL 500mg, she said I can take it if I feel worse I'm worried it will make immune system bad?
column2: If you feel worse, you should definitely take it. If you don't have a fever, cough or shortness of breath, you probably don't need the antibiotics.
column3: Antibiotic   I don't recommend antibiotics for a simple viral upper respiratory tract infection unless examination revealed signs of acute bronchitis or sinusitis.   They are not effective for viral infections like coVid 19 with no bacterial lung involvement either. If you've been exposed to someone with coVid 19 or or if you or someone you were exposed to travelled to a region where it was endemic, get tested  Would you like to video or text chat with me?

column1: I have pain/discomfort in my lungs. I don't experience simultaneous on both lungs and it not always at the hame position. I don't have a head nor do I have high temperature. I sneeze and cough maybe once a day. Do I have corona, should I get tested?
column2: No corona in your lungs. If you have had a sore throat for a few days, and if you sneeze or cough a lot, you probably have it.
column3: Exam needed. You are assuming that the discomfort is coming from both lungs, but pain of pleurisy or pneumonia wouldn't come and go In different sites. I doubt your symptoms are lung related, but fever, chills, sweats, worse cough, shortness of breath, wheezing, warrant testing.. If you've been exposed to someone with covid, or if you or someone you were exposed to  travelled to an affected region, get tested.

column1: I travelled to Mauritius and do not have symptoms. Should I get tested for covid19?

Unless you have traveled to high risk country and or met with someone who has tested positive, in which cases you should be tested.
column3: Self Quarantine . Suggest Self Quarantine for 14 days . If symptomatic , contact your Primary Care Physician or use this platform.

column1: Whatâ€™s worse with the coronavirus, type 1 or type 2 diabetes?

For type 2, the worse is the severe symptoms, the more severe the infection is, and the person is
column3: Diabetes. My answer would be controlled or not. Type 1 or 2 if managed well and treated can still maintain good immunity. If either are out of control then infections of any type more likely. .

column3: Coronavirus and ACEI.   Recent publications including the one from the lancet showed COVID-19 binds to ACE-2 receptor on target cells for entrance. All medications can have some unexpected side effects.    Would you like to video or text chat with me?

column1: If you have wolf Parkinson white syndrome does this make you more of a risk with Covid 19?
column2: No. The wolf in the pack has no effect on the pack as a whole. The pack in the pack is the same as the pack of wolves in the pack. The pack of wolves is the same pack as the pack that has wolf Parkinson. The pack is the pack of pack that has no effect. The pack has alpha 1,2,3,4,5,6,7
column3: Avoid cold/ice... Though untreated WPW Syndrome can be regarded as pre-existing chronic condition, there is no current evidence that one is more susceptible to Covid-19, an infectious disease mostly transmitted through Respiratory Fluid Droplets. Best to follow WHO/CDC guideline on hygiene. Plus avoid cold/ice  drinks/foods. Drink warm water/tea, even chicken soup. Aleve or ibuprofen can be helpful for fever/soreness.

column1: Criteria for COVID test?
column2: If you have a high fever and are concerned about COVID-19, call your GP. Most likely you have a mild cold and not COVID-20, but if you have symptoms that are not resolving you should get tested. Otherwise self isolate and follow the recommendations of your local authorities..
column3: Real vs. textbook. Real-life criteria is different because we don't have enough tests, supplies, or medical staff around the world at this time (March 2020). Textbook criteria are  suspected COVID in hospitalized persons or in those with underlying medical conditions; or persons who got symptoms less than 14 days after (1) contact with a suspect or confirmed COVID patient or (2) travel through high-risk COVID area.

column1: I have been feeling sick for a couple of days now and tried self medication but does not seem to help. I suffer from Polycystic Kidney disease, low blood pressure, Anemic, Endometriosis, Chronic sinus.
column2: If you are having trouble breathing call your doctor or go to ER they can give you instructions to stop smoking and start taking meds. Also make sure you do not smoke or start a new pack of cigarettes. Smoking causes pneumonia and increases your risk of complication
column3: Screen sputum. You may have a bacterial illness such as bronchitis, pneumonia or a sinus infection.  Your PCP may collect sputum, screen for Strep/influenza. COVID-19 is usually associated with a dry cough, but secondary infection may occur. Please see your PCP.

column1: I have had a runny nose and have been coughing and have had on and off headaches. I went to the doctor the first time, he gave me an antibiotic and i got worse then I went back a and he gave me a different one but it seems I still have these symptoms?
column2: Maybe the antibiotic isn't working. Try another one. Try taking Sudafed, ibuprofen, and Zyrtec. If you have to go back to the doctor they can give you another medicine.
column3: Likely a virus.   What you describe is likely caused by a virus, antibiotics  don't do anything against viruses.  Would you like to video or text chat with me?

column1: I am experiencing headache (severity: moderate) (time frame: gradual) (occurred: 1 - 3 hours) (side: front) (worsened by: psychological stress, being tired, menstruation, skipping meals) (unaffected by: bending forward, changes in sleep pattern, sneeze or.
column2: Symptoms of the Headache include Lightheadedness, Dry Coughing and SOB. Lightheadedness is most common. Lightheaded is less likely to be
column3: Many possibilities.   Most people get a headache at some time, such as from colds, infections (usually viruses or sinusitis), lack of sleep, too much driving, long hours on the computer, stress at work, etc.  ..  A bad or severe headache, increasing headache, recurrent headache, weird headache, or one with other worrisome symptoms should be checked by one's primary care doctor or the ER. Can call one's Dr. first to chat.  Would you like to video or text chat with me?

column1: This may sound silly but Iâ€™m wondering, if touch something in store that has Coronavirus 19 on it and it gets on clothes should we go home wash them soon as possible then shower and new clothes on so it dont get on our stuff at home ?
column2: If you have access to a test then yes definitely. I would also recommend using a DEP mask and putting on some clothes that are not currently on your person. Also make sure to keep your hands clean. Keep
column3: Washing clothes.   Although so far it has not been shown to live on surfaces like clothes for as long as it lives on surfaces like plastic and metal, it is definitely good hygienic practice to wash your clothes in the hottest water the garment allows. column1: Re Covid 19 I understand the incubation period of Covid 19 is up to 14 days. But how long is the contagious period? I have read one is contagious 2 days before showing symptoms. Is that true? Are you still contagious until symptom free?
column2: It depends on the severity. Some viruses can be transmitted for up to 14 day. others can be transmitted over 10 days.     If you are not showing symptoms after 2 days without showing symptoms, then you are probably not
column3: Covid. For most people the infection can last up to two weeks. In people who get particularly ill the infection last 4 to 6 weeks. .

column1: Hi I am a health worker and a chronic asthmatic, is it easier for me to contract Corona? Will I survive it with my comorbidity? Should I ask for special leave during this time? I already feel my sinus blocked, very minor sore throat, seldom dry cough.
column2: It is easier to contract corona if you have a history of underlying condition or have been in contact with someone who has been diagnosed or has had corona.   If you have not been
column3: Check with PCP.   Data emerging from preliminary studies in France suggest a decades old medicine, chloroquine may be useful as a preventative drug.   It has been used to prevent malaria for decades & manufactures in the US have announced they are increasing production to meet an expected demand. Your status & what they are doing in your country should be answered by your doc.  Would you like to video or text chat with me?

column1: Throat a bit sore and want to get a good imune booster, especially in light of the virus. Please advise. Have not been in contact with Nyone with the virus.
column2: If sore throat is not associated with COVID-19 then I don't think you need an imune booster.   Best to stay home and keep your distance from everyone else. Keep your distance from the elders.  Would you like to video or text chat with me? I can understand your concern
column3: During this pandemic. Throat pain can be from a strep throat infection (antibiotics needed), a cold or influenza or other virus, or from some other cause such as allergies or irritants. Usually, a person sees the doctor (call first) if the sore throat is bothersome, recurrent, or doesn't go away quickly. COVID-19 infections tend to have cough, whereas strep throat usually lacks cough but has more throat pain. (3/21/20).

column1: I have had a sore throat (glands enlarged in throat) for over a week and I have constant headache. Do I need COVID-19 test. If yes, how do a get someone to come to my house to test.
column2: Call your General Physician. Usually they will be able to assist you. If you have not been in contact with a General Physician in the last 14 days, chances are your symptoms are not worsening. If you are having trouble breathing call your General Phys
column3: Testing.   People are still getting other illnesses than COVID.    Given no cough or shortness of breath, other than watchful waiting COVID should pass in a week or two. Strep, influenza still possible. This testing can be done through your own provider. You can also get your own strep test at pharmacy or many can swab you there.   Would you like to video or text chat with me?

Would you like to video or text chat with me? I can understand your concern.  Would like to see your full examination.  Would it
column3: Phone triage.   Call your GP's office for instructions and identify local resources.   Your symptoms are suggesting sinusitis (other causes still possible) that is frequently viral and self limited. Local regulations should also be followed in such circumstances. Self quarantine will work for all in trying to prevent the spread. Hydration and rest will also work regardless of what the cause for your symptoms is.  Would you like to video or text chat with me?

column1: I have a dry cough and sore throat- it's been a week now and the cough seems to be getting worse- no runny nose or fever, sometimes a headache, no shortness of breath...should I get tested for covid19?
column2: Yes   Call your General Physician and report your symptoms.   They may want to see you, send you to be tested, or may give you other advice. Call now before symptoms worsen.  Would you like to video or text
column3: COVID   Good guidelines can be found at cdc.  gov/coronavirus/2019.  You would be considered low risk. Symptoms last up to two weeks. High probability many will get the disease and testing leads to no change in action at this time.  No obvious therapy (however some encouraging possibilites) and for most people the virus runs its course without incidence. Stay put and talk to your provider. column1: If you've been infected by SARS-CoV-2, develop Covid-19 symptoms and recover, can you: 1) develop immunity to Covid-19 2) infect others after 14 days post-symptom onset & recovery 3) get re-infected later by SARS-CoV-2 despite developing immunity?
column2: No     immunity does not protect you from a virus.    You are either infected or you are not.   Would
column3: Yes, Maybe, Maybe. We presume one is immune to a respiratory virus for a while after getting the infection (that's the way it is with other viruses). A few people have trouble with their antibodies and don't have much immunity. Shedding of viruses sometimes is longer than 14 days. In life, there will always be some people who get reinfected, for whatever reason. Usually one is immune after the infection. (3/21/20).

column1: If I get coronavirus, are there ways to avoid getting other illnesses as well, like pneumonia?
column2: If you get the coronavirus you are quite at risk for getting any respiratory virus including Pneumonia or Coronavirus. So better to stay home and isolate yourself specially from the elders. Stay home. Get someone else to shop for you. Wash your hands often with soap and water. Do not touch your face, mouth or nose with contaminated fingers. Do not look in the
column3: Coronavirus,   COVID-19 has high affinity to the lung, causing viral pneumonia.   Fortunately, most people get only mild respiratory symptoms. Those who have high risks (age over 65, chronic diseases) tend to get pneumonia and complications. The most important way to prevent the complications is not to get infection, practice common sense of prevention. If you catch the infection, start early treatment. column1: My son has a fever, I am concerned due to the coronavirus ?
column2: If your son is not having a fever, then you are probably doing it right. Treat as you would if the Coronavirus was present. Get him to a pediatrician as soon as possible. Ask questions on this forum. He may need antibiotics, a bedside cough syrup and an oral anti-inflammatories prescription. He may also need a chest x ray if he has pneumonia. Ask questions here:
column3: Covid-19 unlikely.   The usual infections in your area of Kwa Zulu Natal are more likely to be the cause of his fever. If he is exposed to someone who is sick with Covid-19, then you need to be concerned.   Meanwhile, treat him as you would have treated him 2 months ago.  If he has shortness of breath or any form of difficulty breathing, get him to a doctor ASAP  Would you like to video or text chat with me?
